Effect of titania polymorph on the properties of CuO/TiO2 catalysts for trace methane combustion Zebao Rui a Yifu Huang a Yu Zheng a Hongbing Ji a ⁎ Xiang Yu b a Department of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, and The Key Lab of Low-carbon Chem & Energy Conservation of Guangdong Province, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou 510275, PR China b Analysis and Test Center of Jinan University, Guangzhou 510632, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Highlights ► More significant anatase to rutile transform happens for CuO/P25 than those for CuO/anatase. ► TiO2 polymorphs affect both the activity and stability of CuO/TiO2 catalysts. ► CuO/rutile shows higher activity than CuO/anatase. ► CuO/rutile shows better stability than the mixed phase TiO2 supported CuO catalyst. Anatase and rutile have the same chemical composition as TiO2 but different crystalline structures and surface structures, which draws effect on the properties of their supported catalysts. Additionally, titania mixture, e.g., Degussa P25, which consists of both anatase and rutile, presents different physicochemical properties with anatase and rutile. In this work, P25-, anatase- or rutile-supported copper oxide catalysts (signed as CuO/P25, CuO/A and CuO/R) were prepared and characterized to study the titania support effect on the physicochemical properties and catalytic properties for the trace CH4 combustion. It is found that the activity of CuO/R is better than the corresponding CuO/A sample when their pore size and specific surface area are comparable, which is attributed to the different chemical states of the copper oxide caused by the different TiO2 support polymorphs. The loading of CuO and subsequent calcination promotes more significant sintering and anatase to rutile transform for CuO/P25 than those for CuO/A. Thus, CuO/R shows better stability than CuO/P25. Keywords Copper oxide P25 Anatase Rutile Surface structure Methane combustion 1 Introduction TiO2, which is a widely used support [1], is known in many cases to enhance the activity due to active phase–support interaction [2–4]. Transition metal oxides supported on TiO2 have found application in various industrial reactions, such as V2O5/TiO2 in selective oxidation of o-xylene to phthalic anhydride [5], and the partial oxidation of hydrocarbons [6], CoO–MoO3/TiO2 for the hydrodesulfurization of hydrocarbon oils [7] and MoO3/TiO2 for the selective photo oxidation of alcohol [8]. Among them, TiO2-supported copper oxide catalysts presented favorable activity in the deep oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons [3,4] and selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO [9]. Titania exists in three main crystalline forms, e.g., anatase, rutile and brookite, and each structure exhibits different physical properties. Among them, anatase and rutile have been widely investigated as catalyst support. Although anatase and rutile have the same chemical composition as TiO2, they have different crystalline structures, which results in different physicochemical properties such as thermal stability, density, and band gap as well as surface structures. More interesting is that the mixture P25 (Degussa), which consists of anatase and rutile, presents different physicochemical properties with both anatase and rutile and has frequently been used as a benchmark for photocatalysts [10–12]. It is well known that most catalytic reactions over heterogeneous catalysts take place on the surface of the catalysts or at the interface of active species and support. It is inferred that different crystalline-structured TiO2 supported catalysts might exhibit different physio-chemical properties and catalytic properties [2,11,13–19]. Thus, it is crucial to investigate the interaction between the transition metal oxide and TiO2 support for elucidating the nature of the catalysts and exploring the key factors in controlling the properties of the catalysts. Notably, most of researchers focused on catalysts with anatase used as support [3,4,20–23]. Few information could be found about rutile supported catalysts and P25 supported catalysts (except for the reports in the field of photocatalysis), as well as the difference among these supports [2,13,17–19]. Inconsistent results were also reported by different groups for different reaction systems. Sermon et al. [13] found that, in respect to the reduction properties of supported Cu2+ species, rutile was different from anatase. After reduction at 700K, very little of the copper may have been intercalated into the anatase support, but that on rutile such an intercalation may have been significant. Afterward, the structure–reactivity studies of the different vanadia–titania catalysts by del Arco et al. [2] suggested that the specific titania phase was not a critical parameter in determining the physical or chemical nature of the surface vanadia phase. Li et al. [17,18] made a comparative investigation into SMSI for anatase and rutile titania supported palladium catalyst by EPR using CO as probe molecules. It was discovered that even pre-reduced by H2 at lower temperature resulted in SMSI for anatase titania supported palladium catalyst, but not for rutile titania supported palladium catalyst. Zhu et al. [19] studied the support effect of titania on the physicochemical properties and catalytic properties of anatase- or rutile-supported copper oxide catalysts for the NO reduction by CO reaction. The results indicated that copper oxide supported on rutile was more active than that on anatase, which might result from Cu+ species in CuO/rutile sample formed during the reaction due to its stepwise reduction behavior. Despite the studies on different crystalline-structured TiO2 supported catalysts mentioned above, the nature of the interactions between the active species and the support is still unclear, and it is still difficult to predict which structure is preferred for a certain reaction because of the inconsistent conclusions in the literature and the complexity of the interaction. In addition, the potential of P25 as a heterogeneous catalyst support needs to be explored. The present work focuses on the application and comparison of TiO2 supports with different crystalline structures (anatase, rutile and P25) in the field of catalytic combustion of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Copper oxides are chosen as the active species due to its high activity among the transition metal oxides for combustion [3,4]. Trace methane combustion reaction is used as a model reaction. Because methane is the most refractory hydrocarbon, and the release of unburned CH4 during homogeneous combustion is a serious problem, given that CH4 is a greenhouse gas with an effect that is 20 times higher than that of CO2 [24]. It is found that the polymorphs of titania support affect both the activity and stability of CuO/TiO2 catalysts in trace CH4 combustion reaction. CuO/rutile shows higher activity than the corresponding CuO/anatase sample when their pore size and specific surface area are comparable, and better stability than the mixed phase TiO2 supported CuO catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The titania supports with different crystalline structures used are anatase TiO2 (99%, Alfa Aesar), rutile TiO2 (99.5%, Alfa Aesar) and AEROXIDE TiO2 P25 (≥99.5%, Degussa AG). These supports were respectively signed as A-TiO2, R-TiO2 and P25 in this work. To obtain R-TiO2 with a high surface area, isolation of rutile TiO2 particles from P25 by treatment with a 10% HF solution was adopted [25]. The rutile isolated from P25 was signed as iso-R. Titania supported copper oxide catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method, with supports impregnated in an aqueous solution containing the requisite amount of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (99.5%, Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagent Factory, China) for 1h under ultrasonication. The impregnated catalysts were dried at 100°C overnight and then calcined at 600°C for 6h in air with a heating rate of 10°C/min. For simplicity, each catalyst will be designated according to the copper loading, for example, 5CuO/A represents the copper oxide catalyst supported on A-TiO2 with 5wt.% of CuO. Three different copper loadings, e.g., 3, 5 and 7wt.%, were adopted. The surface density should vary due to different BET surface areas of A-TiO2, R-TiO2 and P25. Bulk CuO was prepared by thermal decomposition of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O in air for 6h at 600°C. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The morphologies of the catalysts were observed by a FEI TECNAI 10 transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The phase purity and crystal structure of the catalysts were examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD, D-MAX 2200 VPC), using monochromatic Cu Kα radiation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on an ESCALAB250 (VG) using Al Kα (1486.6eV) radiation. The applied power was operated at 15kV and 20mA. The base pressure in the analysis chamber was less than 10−8 Pa. Smoothing, background removal, and peak fitting were carried out with a least squares fitting program (Peak FIT, Sea Solve Software). All the peaks were corrected with the C 1s peak at 284.8eV as the reference. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution of the samples were measured with a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument using adsorption of N2 at 77K. Prior to adsorption analyses, the catalysts were degassed in a flowing N2 at 300°C for 3h. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) profiles were recorded on a TP-5085 instrument supplied from Tianjin Xianquan Industry and Trade Development Co., Ltd., China. The reduction gas with a flow rate of 60mL/min was 10vol.% H2 in N2. Peak fitting was carried out with a least squares fitting program (Peak FIT, Sea Solve Software). Raman spectra were recorded on a Laser Micro-Raman Spectrometer (Renishaw In VIA). A Ar− laser excitation sources at 514 .5nm with a power of 20mW was used. The resolution was 1cm−1 and only 1 scan was recorded for each spectrum due to the high signal to noise ratio. 2.3 Testing of catalysts The catalytic tests were performed using a continuous-flow quartz fixed-bed reactor (i.d.=7mm) under atmospheric pressure. Approximately 200mg catalyst with particle sizes in the range of 200–450μm was packed. Experiments were performed at a constant GHSV (gas hourly space velocity) of 30,000mLh−1 g−1. GHSV is defined as the total flow rate of gas at STP per unit weight of catalyst. The feed concentration of CH4 was 1.0vol.% in synthetic air. The composition of the reactants/products mixture was analyzed with an on-line gas chromatograph (GC7890II) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a TDX-01 column. All conversions were calculated on the basis of the CH4 concentrations. 3 Results 3.1 Performance of CuO/TiO2 with different TiO2 polymorphs Fig. 1 shows that the CH4 conversion increases with increasing temperature at the reaction temperature from 200 to 600°C for all the samples. For titania supported CuO catalysts with 3wt.%, 5wt.% and 7wt.% loadings, an activity order toward CH4 conversion is observed for the different titania polymorphs, i.e., P25>A-TiO2 >R-TiO2. The activity of CuO/iso-R shows a distinct dependence on the CuO loading. The variations of CH4 conversions at different CuO loadings together with the pure iso-R-TiO2 and pure CuO have also been explored, as shown in Fig. 1D. It is apparent that the activity increases with increasing CuO loading for (3%, 5% and 7%) CuO/iso-R. As a result, although the activity of 3CuO/iso-R is much poorer than that of 3CuO/P25, the activities of 5CuO/iso-R and 5CuO/P25 are comparable, and the activity of 7CuO/iso-R is better than that of 7CuO/P25. Additionally, CuO/iso-R catalysts with different CuO loading amounts are all considerably more active than pure iso-R-TiO2 and pure CuO. 3.2 Stability test Fig. 2 shows the long-term operation of the oxidation of 1vol.% CH4 in simulated air over 5CuO/iso-R and 5CuO/P25 catalysts at 600°C. As shown, 5CuO/iso-R exhibits superior stability than 5CuO/P25. The CH4 conversion over 5CuO/iso-R at the beginning is 97.8%, and it deceases slightly to 95.9% after a 50h reaction. While it decreases rapidly from 96.3% to 88.7% over 5CuO/P25 under a parallel reaction condition. 3.3 Morphology of the CuO/TiO2 catalysts Table 1 shows specific surface area, average pore size, and pore volume of the different samples. In general, both the BET surface area and the pore volume decrease after CuO loading and the sequential calcination, except for the samples 5CuO/R and 5CuO/iso-R. After a 50h operation at 600°C, the specific surface area and the pore volume further decrease to 7.5m2/g and 0.013cm3/g for 5CuO/P25, while no obvious change in both properties happens for 5CuO/iso-R. Fig. 3 shows the TEM images of the supports, as prepared catalysts and the spent catalysts after a 50h stability test. As shown, A-TiO2 (Fig. 3A) is made of the small particles, roughly ∼30nm in size, aggregated together. While P25 (Fig. 3D) contains at least two types of particles, which are roughly 20–30nm and 50–60nm in size, respectively. These results agree well with the reported results in literature [10,25,26]. The group with larger particle size is rutile phase, and the group with smaller size can be assigned to the anatase part. These particles exist separately in P25 [10,25,26]. In addition, the rutile particles could be isolated from P25 with HF solution treatment, and there was only a small decrease in the size of rutile particles after the treatment [10,25]. As shown in Fig. 3G, iso-R-TiO2 is in the same range with the rutile particles in P25. After deposition of CuO and the following calcination, the particles size of 5CuO/A and 5CuO/P25 becomes larger obviously (Fig. 3B and E), indicating a sintering happens in this process. While no obvious change in the morphology of 5CuO/iso-R (Fig. 3H) in comparison that of iso-R-TiO2 is observed. 5CuO/R (Fig. 3C) is composed of the largest particles among these samples, roughly 460nm in size. After a 50h operation at 600°C, obvious sintering can be observed over 5CuO/P25-spent (Fig. 3F), while in the case of the 5CuO/iso-R-spent (Fig. 3I), no significant change in the morphology happens. These results are consistent with the N2 adsorption data listed in Table 1. 3.4 Chemical state of copper species in the CuO/TiO2 catalysts 3.4.1 XRD characterization Table 2 lists some characteristic XRD data for the CuO/TiO2 catalysts and supports. A-TiO2, 3CuO/A and 5CuO/A only consist of pure anatase (JCPDS file no. 21-1272), while for 7CuO/A, CuO (JCPDS file no. 48-1548) is detected except for the anatase, of which two strong lines are at 2θ =35.5° and 38.7°. The CuO line at 2θ =38.7° unfortunately interferes with a peak from anatase at 2θ =38.6°. So in this work, the CuO line at 2θ =35.5° is chosen as an index for CuO. Among all these four samples, no rutile (JCPDS file no. 65-0190) is detected because no peak is apparent around 2θ =27.4°, where the strongest line from rutile is positioned. In addition, upon supporting CuO, the crystallinity of the support increases as is seen from the narrowing of the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the strongest anatase peak. For all the three R-TiO2 supported CuO samples, CuO lines at 2θ =35.5° appear. There is no obvious difference between the FWHM of R-TiO2 and those R-TiO2 supported CuO catalysts, indicating no crystal enlargement happens upon loading CuO on R-TiO2 and thereafter calcinations at 600°C. P25, on the other hand, consists of both anatase and rutile. The phase contents of the samples can be estimated from the respective XRD peak integral intensities using the following equation [27] (1) f R = I R K I A + I R where f R is the fraction of rutile phase in the powder. I A and I R are the X-ray intensities of the anatase (101) and rutile (110) diffraction peaks, respectively. K =0.79 for f R <0.8 and K =0.68 for f R ≥0.8. For the 3CuO/P25, 5CuO/P25 and 7CuO/P25 samples, CuO line at 2θ =35.5° appears. In addition, it can be found that a serious phase transform from anatase to rutile happens upon deposition of copper and subsequent calcinations. No anatase is detected in 5CuO/P25-spent, indicating nearly all anatase transforms to rutile during the 50h of operation. For all the iso-R-TiO2 supported CuO samples, only rutile (JCPDS file no. 65-0190) is detected. This indicates on one hand the effective isolation of anatase from P25 by the HF solution treatment [25], on the other hand the good dispersion of CuO x particles, even for 5CuO/iso-R-spent and 7CuO/iso-R. 3.4.2 Reducibility of the CuO/TiO2 catalysts As shown in Fig. 4 , TPR profile for 5CuO/A shows three peaks at about 158, 192 and 215°C, respectively, with a peak area ratio of S1:S2:S3=35:48:17. The TPR curve for 5CuO/iso-R presents three peaks at about 150, 174 and 206°C (S1:S2:S3=22:50:28), respectively, which are lower than the corresponding peaks for 5CuO/A. TPR profile for 5CuO/R presents one big peak at 223°C and two weak peaks at 183 and 269°C (S1:S2:S3=3:90:7), respectively. TPR profile for 5CuO/P25 shows three peaks at about 146, 167 and 205°C (S1:S2:S3=39:29:32). After a 50h on stream operation at 600°C, these peaks move to high temperatures at 151, 185 and 214°C for 5CuO/P25-spent (S1:S2:S3=13:57:30), respectively. In addition, the first peak has become smaller, the second one has become broader, and the third remains unchanged. The three reduction peaks in the TPR curve of the 5CuO/iso-R-spent also move to high temperatures at 194, 223 and 264°C (S1:S2:S3=46:44:10), respectively, after a 50h on stream operation. The only difference is that the relative intensities of the first two peaks get strengthened. 3.4.3 XPS characterization The binding energies, half widths, Cu/Ti surface ratio and the intensity ratio between the Cu 2p3/2 shake-up satellite and the main peak are summarized in Table 3 for CuO/TiO2 catalysts, supports and CuO. The Cu 2p3/2, Ti 2p3/2, and O 1s binding energies in Table 3 of the samples agree well with published data for CuO/TiO2 samples and TiO2 [3]. The Cu 2p3/2 binding energy for the copper oxide supported on TiO2 is about the same for the pure CuO, which is about 934.3eV [3]. The Ti 2p3/2 binding energy is at 458.34–458.98eV. As regards the O 1s binding energy value, this is 530.3eV for CuO and is about the same for the CuO/TiO2 catalysts and the pure supports. The intensity ratio between the Cu 2p3/2 shake-up satellite and the main peak are 0.473, 0.331, 0.370, 0.339 and 0.540 for the 5CuO/A, 5CuO/R, 5CuO/P25, 5CuO/iso-R and CuO particles, respectively. The ratio for 5CuO/iso-R-spent is increased from 0.339 to 0.405, and it is increased from 0.370 to 0.485 for 5CuO/P25-spent during the 50h on stream operation. The XPS data in Table 3 also show different Cu/Ti surface ratios for 5Cu/A, 5Cu/R, 5Cu/P25 and 5Cu/iso-R, which are, respectively 0.259, 0.193, 0.289 and 0.219. With the same crystallite structure, Cu/Ti surface ratio of 5CuO/iso-R is higher than that of 5CuO/R. After a 50h operation, the ratio increase only from 0.219 to 0.222 for 5CuO/iso-R, while it increases dramatically from 0.289 to 0.353 for 5CuO/P25. 3.4.4 Raman spectra The Raman spectra of the TiO2 supported CuO catalysts and TiO2 supports with different polymorphs are shown in Fig. 5 for the region 100–800cm−1. The A-TiO2 support shows the characteristic spectrum of anatase with four strong bands at 142 (Eg), 396 (B1g), 515 (A1g +B1g), and 638 (Eg)cm−1 [3,28]. In the case of 5CuO/A, only the bands from A-TiO2 are present, and there are no bands from CuO (which has the strongest band at 296cm−1 [3]), indicating that the CuO species are well dispersed. However, the intensity of the A-TiO2 bands strongly decreases in comparison with those for A-TiO2 support. The R-TiO2 shows that the B1g (143cm−1), Eg (447cm−1) and A1g (612cm−1) modes as well as the two-phonon bands at ∼240cm−1 are the major features of rutile TiO2 [29,30]. Similar to 5CuO/A, only the support bands were seen for 5CuO/R, and no bands from CuO were observed, although CuO crystallites over 5CuO/R was detected by XRD. Compared with the R-TiO2 spectrum, the bands were much less intense. The spectrum of the P25 support shows strong characteristic spectrum of anatase, together with the weak bands from rutile. While the spectrum of the 5CuO/P25 shows strong characteristic spectrum of rutile, and the bands for anatase are very weak. These results indicate that the loading of CuO and the sequential calcinations cause a phase change from anatase to rutile over 5CuO/P25. After a 50h stability test, no bands for anatase can be observed, indicating a complete transform from anatase to rutile. The spectra of iso-R-TiO2, 5CuO/iso-R and 5CuO/iso-R-spent are the same, namely only the bands for rutile can be detected. 4 Discussion 4.1 Influence of TiO2 polymorph on CuO x structure In this work, commercial A-TiO2, R-TiO2, P25 and the rutile part isolated from P25 with HF solution (iso-R-TiO2) were used as the supports respectively. These supports possess different phase structures and morphologies, especially the different BET areas, as listed in Table 1. Thus, different CuO x structures and CuO x –support interaction are expected. For 5CuO/R, due to the small BET surface area of the support, the CuO crystallites accumulate on the support surface resulting in a lower Cu/Ti surface ratio (Table 3), which can also be seen from the XRD results. Sintering of 5CuO/A happens after CuO loading and the sequential calculation, as demonstrated by the N2 adsorption results listed in Table 1. However, no crystallite CuO was detected by XRD and a higher Cu/Ti surface ratio was measured from XPS. This is because the CuO crystallites, which form or grow in size simultaneously with sintering of the support, can accumulate on the support surfaces, spread over and cover the new surfaces created as a result of the sintering the support surface [3]. Under the current conditions, the CuO x monolayer dispersion threshold over A-TiO2 should be around 5wt.% CuO, as speculated from the XRD data in Table 2. Possessing of the large surface area similar to that of A-TiO2, the monolayer CuO loading amount on P25 should be around 5wt.% CuO [21]. However, the TEM observation (Fig. 3) and N2 adsorption measurements (Table 1) indicate a more significant sintering for 5CuO/P25 than that for 5CuO/A. As a result, the crystalline CuO form over 5CuO/P25, and a high Cu/Ti surface ratio is found. It can be understood considering the loss of surface area which occurs upon deposition of copper and subsequent calcinations (as listed in Table 1). The CuO crystallites firstly spread over the new surface, and the excess CuO crystallites accumulates on the surface due to the severe sintering of the P25 support. Thus, although the CuO crystallites was detected by XRD, the 5CuO/P25 still possess of the highest Cu/Ti surface ratio. In addition, although the promotion to the anatase–rutile transition by CuO has been reported in literature [20], the results in this work show that such a promotion in P25 support is more significant than that in pure A-TiO2 support. A possible explanation for the different behaviors of CuO/A and CuO/P25 upon sintering is their different anatase to rutile transformation rates. Amores et al. [31] proposed that the sintering of the rutile particles produced by anatase phase transformation was speeded up due to the heat produced by the phase transformation itself, which was referred as ‘phase transformation-induced sintering’. Due to the relative large surface area of iso-R-TiO2 support and its anti-sintering properties (Table 1), the CuO x monolayer dispersion threshold over iso-R-TiO2 should be around 7wt.% CuO, as speculated from the XRD results. Considering the results previously reported for CuOx on the anatase polymorph, the TPR spectrum for 5CuO/A shows good agreement with those reported by Bond et al. [32] showing reduction peaks at about 140, 160, and 200°C. In comparison with the results reported in the literature [4,20], the peak at 158°C and 192°C can be assigned to the reduction of the highly dispersed copper oxide, and the peak at about 215°C is identified as being due to the reduction of bulk CuO not interacting with the support. It should be noted that some groups [19,21,22] reported two reduction peaks for CuO/A. Except for the effect of experimental factors, the overlap of the peaks should also be considered. For 5CuO/iso-R, TPR profile also presents three peaks which are lower than the corresponding peaks for 5CuO/A. Zhu et al. [19] assigned the two low temperature reduction peaks to the reduction of Cu2+ →Cu+ and Cu+ →Cu0, and the high temperature reduction peak to the reduction of crystalline CuO. Giordano et al. [33] simulated the interaction between copper atoms and the (110) plane of rutile by the density function method. Their results suggested that Cu atoms on bridge oxygen sites were more stable than on other sites such as terminal oxygen sites and Cu atoms could transfer part of outer layer electrons to support and form Cu δ+ ions, where δ was between 0 and 2. This seems to suggest that Cu δ+ might be stable on a rutile surface. Accordingly, two low temperature reduction peaks centered at 150 and 174°C could be attributed to the reduction of Cu2+ →Cu+ and Cu+ →Cu0, respectively. The high temperature reduction peaks centered at 206°C should be attributed to the reduction of crystalline CuO. However, it should be noted that the peak area ratio of the two low temperature peaks is not unit. The possible reason is that the reduction peak at 174°C not only represents partly Cu+ →Cu0 also comes from the reduction of the crystalline CuO. The different reduction behaviors for the supported CuO catalysts with different loading amounts per support surface area was reported by Amano et al. [34], who reported one-electron reducibility of isolated copper oxide on alumina with low loading. Because of the low surface area of R-TiO2, the CuO mainly exists as crystalline CuO over 5CuO/R, and the step reduction of the dispersed CuO is more obscure. Although 5CuO/P25 has been reported in the literature that copper species could enhance the photocatalytic efficiency of P25 [35–37], its reduction behavior and the role of copper species (e.g., Cu2+, Cu+, or Cu0) during the reaction is still unclear. In this work, the loading of CuO and subsequent calcinations promotes significant anatase to rutile transform for 5CuO/P25. Thus, similar reduction behavior with that for 5CuO/iso-R is observed, and a profound interaction between CuO and the support can be expected. Two low temperature reduction peaks centered at 146 and 167°C could be attributed to the reduction of Cu2+ →Cu+ and Cu+ →Cu0, respectively, while the high temperature reduction peaks centered at 205°C should be attributed to the reduction of crystalline CuO. Taking into consideration that TiO2 is an n-type semiconductor, the n-type defects, i.e., Ti3+ ions and oxygen vacancies on the surface under a reducing atmosphere, tends to donate electric charges to the Cu2+ ions, i.e., promotes the reduction of copper oxide species [22,38,39]. The enhancement of the reducibility of copper oxide species should be related to the interaction between the copper oxide species with TiO2 support [22]. Thus, the reduction peaks of dispersed CuO x over 5CuO/P25 are lower than the corresponding peaks for 5CuO/iso-R. Different CuO x structures and CuO x –support interaction over these samples can be further speculated from the XPS results. It has been well established that for copper species the shake-up peak and the higher Cu 2p3/2 binding energy are two major XPS characteristics of CuO, while the absence of the shake-up peak and the lower Cu 2p3/2 binding energy are the characteristics of the reduced copper species [21,40]. In this work, the XPS spectra of the catalysts all show Cu 2p3/2 satellite/main peak ratios which are slightly less than the corresponding value for CuO, indicating Cu2+ species were partly reduced. It was suggested that the creation of Cu δ+ (0< δ <2) species was related to the reduction of dispersed Cu2+ species by photo reduction in the spectrometer [3,4,23]. The difference is a consequence of the dispersed copper oxide species being more sensitive than bulk CuO to photo reduction in the spectrometer. The intensity ratio between the Cu 2p3/2 shake-up satellite and the main peak of 5CuO/A is closer to that of CuO particles, while they are much lower for 5CuO/R and 5CuO/iso-R, indicating that less Cu δ+ (0< δ <2) species exist in 5CuO/A. As reported previously, dispersed copper oxide species on A-TiO2 were stable and hard to be reduced to Cu+ species completely under XPS measurement [19]. Zhu et al. [19] reported a different behavior of copper oxide on A-TiO2 and R-TiO2, i.e., the main copper species was Cu+ species for CuO/R samples with a low copper loading during XPS measurement, while the main copper species was Cu2+ species on CuO/A samples. And they attributed such a behavior to the support effect of anatase and rutile. As in 5CuO/P25, most of its anatase part was transformed to rutile phase, its XPS characterization results are similar to those for 5CuO/iso-R and 5CuO/R. These results suggested that the reduction behavior of dispersed copper oxide species on rutile from Cu2+ to Cu+ species was easier compared to that on anatase. In addition, these results also suggested that Cu δ+ (0< δ <2) species were stable on rutile under certain reduction conditions. 4.2 Performance of CuOx/TiO2 with different polymorphs A complication comparing the performances of copper oxide on the four supports is that the distribution between copper oxide species and the interaction between copper oxide and support differ. As reported in the literature, dispersed copper oxide species and small CuO particle were the main active species for the supported CuO catalysts [3,4,19,23,31]. According to the TPR profile of 5CuO/R, most copper is in the form of bulk CuO, resulting in low coverage of the support with dispersed species interacting with the titania, a fact that contributes to its lower activity [3]. In addition, the poor performance of CuO/R partly can be due to its small surface area [3]. However, although the pore size and specific surface area of 5CuO/A are larger than those for 5CuO/iso-R and there in no obvious difference in CuO dispersion between these two samples, the activity of 5CuO/iso-R is much better. Clearly, the different behavior of copper oxide on anatase and rutile should closely correlate to the support effect of anatase and rutile. Sokolovskii [41] proposed that efficient catalysts of complete oxidation must have a large number of sites that can coordinate the molecule of oxygen and must quite easily donate and accept electrons. Accordingly, the existence of Cu δ+ (0< δ <2) species are beneficial for this reaction, which is superior for oxygen coordination, electron transfer and dissociation than Cu2+ species. Because Cu δ+ (0< δ <2) species form easily and exist stably over rutile compared to that on anatase under certain reduction conditions, CuO/iso-R shows higher activity than CuO/A. Due to the phase transform from anatase to rutile during the CuO/P25 preparation process, the interaction between copper oxide with the support is similar to that in CuO/iso-R. Thus, despite the severe sintering in CuO/P25, its activity is higher than the corresponding CuO/A sample. Especially, the CuO crystallites can spread over the new surface due to the severe sintering of the P25 support. Despite the excess CuO crystallites accumulates on the surface, the 5CuO/P25 still possess of a Cu/Ti surface ratio and its initial activity is comparable with 5CuO/iso-R. With further increasing the CuO loading, more CuO crystallites are formed over 7CuO/P25 contributing little to its activity. While for 7CuO/iso-R, a well copper oxide dispersion is still obtained due to the large surface area and good stability of iso-R-TiO2 support (Table 2). Among the samples examined, 7CuO/iso-R performs the best, with a 98% CH4 conversion at 600°C, which is among the best results for the same reaction over CuO based catalysts reported in the literature [42–44]. For example, Luo et al. [44] obtained a 90% CH4 conversion over the bio-template prepared 10%CuO–ZrO2 catalyst at 590°C with a reaction flow of 5vol.% CH4/10vol.% O2 and GHSV=45,000h−1. However, the preparation method and CuO loading amount need to be further optimized in the future study to obtain a better performance. Because it was found that the activity increased with CuO loading amount for the CuO loading amount of 3–7wt.% over iso-TiO2 in this work. M’Ramadj et al. [45] obtained a CH4 conversion of 98% at 500°C over 20%CuO/ZSM-5 catalyst with a feed gas of 0.2vol.% CH4 and 4vol.% air and GHSV=30,000h−1. 4.3 Catalyst stability In the harsh atmosphere of reaction system, e.g., the hot spot in the catalyst bed and sintering of the catalyst due to the exothermic oxidation reactions and the high operation temperature, the deactivation of the supported fine particles catalysts happens easily. The deactivation of samples is caused by sintering of both the support and the copper oxide. Sintering of the support is evident for 5CuO/P25(spent) considering Table 1, which shows loss of surface area in agreement with the TEM observation after use of the samples. 5CuO/iso-R shows no loss of surface area upon use, possibly because it consists of larger, more stable crystallites. Sintering of the copper oxide for 5CuO/P25(spent) during use of the samples is apparent considering the reduction peak from dispersed CuO x species in TPR profile (Fig. 4). After a 50h on stream operation at 600°C, the TPR reduction peaks for 5CuO/P25-spent move to high temperatures, and the peak intensity of the first two peaks changes. Finally, similar to the reduction behavior for 5CuO/R, the step reduction of the dispersed CuO over 5CuO/P25(spent) also gets mitigated due to the severe sintering for both CuO particles and the support. This point can also be seen from the change of intensity ratio between the Cu 2p3/2 shake-up satellite and the main peak for 5CuO/P25(spent), which increases from 0.370 for 5CuO/P25 to 0.485. Although the TPR profile for 5CuO/iso-R(spent) shows the move of the reduction peaks to higher temperatures, the difference is that the relative intensities of the first two peaks get strengthened, indicating that there is still a good dispersion of copper species over iso-R-TiO2. XRD results (Table 2) also indicate no crystallite CuO is formed over 5CuO/iso-R(spent). The move of the TPR peaks to higher temperatures for 5CuO/iso-R(spent) is probably because of the size growth of the dispersed CuO particles [3,46], but not to a extent that crystalline CuO is formed. These sintered copper oxide particles contact with the TiO2 support loosely, which leads to less promotion effect on the reduction behaviors of these copper oxide particles. The present results can thus explain the deactivation of the samples. The severe deactivation of 5CuO/P25 (spent) is a consequence of its severe sintering of both the active phase and support. CuO/iso-R shows superior stability for methane combustion. 5 Conclusions The study mainly focuses on the application and comparison of TiO2 supports with different crystalline structure in the field of catalytic combustion of trace methane. The following conclusions can be drawn: (1) the loading of CuO and subsequent calcinations promotes more significant sintering and anatase to rutile transform for P25 supported CuO catalysts than those for anatase supported CuO samples. (2) Cu δ+ (0< δ <2) species form easily and exist stably over rutile compared to that on anatase under certain reduction conditions. (3) The activity of CuO/rutile is better than the corresponding CuO/anatase sample when their pore size and specific surface area are comparable, which is attributed to the different chemical state of the copper oxide caused by the different TiO2 support polymorphs. (4) In comparison with the mixed phase TiO2 (e.g. P25) supported CuO catalysts, CuO/rutile shows better stability due to the stable crystallites of rutile. Our observation, namely that the polymorphs of titania support affect both the activity and stability of CuO/TiO2 catalysts in organic compound combustion reaction should help in guiding the further exploration of practical high-yield TiO2-based and supported catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Anatase and rutile have the same chemical composition as TiO2 but different crystalline structures and surface structures, which draws effect on the properties of their supported catalysts. Additionally, titania mixture, e.g., Degussa P25, which consists of both anatase and rutile, presents different physicochemical properties with anatase and rutile. In this work, P25-, anatase- or rutile-supported copper oxide catalysts (signed as CuO/P25, CuO/A and CuO/R) were prepared and characterized to study the titania support effect on the physicochemical properties and catalytic properties for the trace CH4 combustion. It is found that the activity of CuO/R is better than the corresponding CuO/A sample when their pore size and specific surface area are comparable, which is attributed to the different chemical states of the copper oxide caused by the different TiO2 support polymorphs. The loading of CuO and subsequent calcination promotes more significant sintering and anatase to rutile transform for CuO/P25 than those for CuO/A. Thus, CuO/R shows better stability than CuO/P25.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of titania polymorph on the properties of CuO/TiO2 catalysts for trace methane combustion
